I would just like to note that there are dependencies here (eg. if there source models, then I feel head models are a necessity, or if there is averaged data, I feel prepreoceesed and epoched data are a necessity)
column15: This depends strongly on the experiment. However, Time-frequency, epoched, preprocessed raw, and average data are most common.
column16: MNE-Python;EEGLab;Brainstorm;FieldTrip;BESA;Your own custom scripts;eConnectome, and many other smaller packages

column14: Preprocessed stimuli that are synchronized with signals.  For example, I work with sounds, so sounds are recorded as stimulus channels with EEG and iEEG. I then will save preprocessed versions of, for example, the stimulus envelope, spectrogram, waveform, phonetic transcriptions, etc.
column15: epoched and filtered data, plus annotations/preprocessed stimuli

column14: Segmented anatomy file/head models to associate with EEG
Any information involving trigger types and task conditions for raw, and settings and versions of software used for processed data

column2: Yes and no. I mean, it seems well-intended, but one size fits all for M/EEG seems impractical to me. Unlike fMRI where a specific preprocessing is mandatory, for M/EEG there is no ONE way of doing things.

column14: To my mind, the annotations are the important one b/c that is what prevents us from quickly moving to analysis.
column15: Usually, deriving a cleaned and epoched version is the most important thing. We prefer not to keep time-frequency and connectivity around after analysis b/c they take up so much disk space.

column14: As long as scripts are provided, most processes can simply be rerun on the users system. Manual processes such as bad channels, rejected segments/epochs should be indicated. A final, completely processed file would also be useful to quickly reproduce results.
